SubTopics: Determine the meaning of and use words with affixes such as mis-, sub-, -ment, and -ity/ty and roots such as auto, graph, and meter.
Content: The prefix un- helps the reader know that the word u͟n͟f͟a͟m͟i͟l͟i͟a͟r in paragraph 8 means —

Key.Rationale: The prefix un‐ does not mean “partly,” and the author does not include context that supports that baby elephants are stressed by something “partly known.”
“Together” is not the meaning of the prefix un-, and there is no context to support the idea that baby elephants are stressed by something that is “known together.”

The reader cannot use the meaning of the prefix un‐ in the word u͟n͟f͟a͟m͟i͟l͟i͟a͟r or any context in the selection to support the idea that baby elephants are stressed by something that they have “known in the past.”

In paragraph 8, the author describes how baby elephants react when stressed by “an u͟n͟f͟a͟m͟i͟l͟i͟a͟r situation.” The reader can use this context and the prefix un‐ to determine that the word u͟n͟f͟a͟m͟i͟l͟i͟a͟r means “not familiar” or “not known.”

SubTopics: Retell, paraphrase, or summarize texts in ways that maintain meaning and logical order.
Content: What is the best summary of the selection?

F.Choice: Loud trumpeting sounds are just one of the sounds elephants make. They also make rumbles, barks, snorts, and cries to communicate with members of the herd

Key.Rationale: Only sounds are described in this summary, but there are many more ways that elephants communicate, making this summary incomplete.

G.Choice: Elephants have many more ways of communicating than most people might think. Elephants use touch, smell, noise, and movement to give one another messages

Key.Rationale: This is the most complete summary of the selection. The main idea of the selection (elephant communication) is described, along with the different types of communication that correspond to the different sections (“Sound,” “Body Language,” “Smell,” and “Touch”).

H.Choice: An elephant’s trunk lets an elephant share messages such as “Let’s play” or “Danger!” The trunk has a sensitive tip for touching other elephants and picking up smells.

Key.Rationale: This summary is incomplete. Different uses of the elephant’s trunk are described in this summary. The ways in which an elephant produces sound and the different types of body language an elephant uses are main ideas that are not included in this summary.

J.Choice: People and elephants both have a larynx, a body part that lets them make sounds. Elephants “talk” in low sounds, and elephants also use their sense of touch and smell a lot.

Key.Rationale: Small details, such as the comparison between elephants and humans, are focused on in this summary instead of the overall idea of elephant communication, so this is not the best summary of the selection.

SubTopics: Analyze the author's use of print and graphic features to achieve specific purposes.
Content: Based on information in the selection, what is the most likely reason the author includes the photograph of the baby elephant standing close to its mother?

A.Choice: To suggest that the baby elephant is warning its mother that there is danger nearby

Key.Rationale: The author mentions that an elephant reacts to danger by flaring its ears or sticking out its tail (paragraph 5), which are not shown in the photograph.

B.Choice: To show the reader what the baby elephant does to try to get its mother to play with it

Key.Rationale: The author mentions in paragraph 8 that baby elephants stand close to their mother when they are tired of playing, so the reader can conclude that the author does not include the photograph in order to show what the baby elephant does when it wants its mother to play with it.

C.Choice: To show the reader what the baby elephant does when it wants its mother to know it is hungry

Key.Rationale: Elephants’ behavior when hungry is not mentioned in the selection, so the author does not want to show what the baby elephant does when hungry by including the photograph.

D.Choice: To suggest that the baby elephant feels safe and protected when it is near its mother

Key.Rationale: In the photograph, the baby elephant is standing close to its mother. In paragraph 8, next to the photograph, the author explains that when a calf is tired or stressed, it will go to its mother for comfort. The reader can conclude that the author includes the photograph “to suggest that the baby elephant feels safe and protected when it is near its mother.”

SubTopics: Features such as pronunciation guides and diagrams to support understanding.
Content: How do the subheadings provide an overview of the selection?

F.Choice: They identify the ways elephants communicate.

Key.Rationale: A new way that elephants communicate is identified in each subheading: “Sound,” “Body Language,” “Smell,” and “Touch.”

G.Choice: They describe important roles in an elephant herd.

Key.Rationale: The subheadings are words that are used to describe ways of communicating that all elephants use, not roles within an elephant herd.

H.Choice: They tell why elephants need attention.

Key.Rationale: Although the author provides information about baby elephants needing attention from their mother (paragraph 8), the subheadings are not included to tell why elephants need attention.

J.Choice: They compare ways that elephants find food.

Key.Rationale: The subheadings are included to describe ways elephants communicate, not how they find food, and food is only mentioned within the section titled “Smell.”

SubTopics: Use text evidence to support an appropriate response.
Content: Which sentence from the selection supports the idea that elephant herds try to guard themselves from danger?

A.Choice: But an elephant’s huge larynx produces very low sounds. (paragraph 3)

Key.Rationale: Elephants’ vocal communication is described in this sentence, but it is not mentioned in relation to danger.

B.Choice: Some gestures — a twitch of an ear, a wag of the head — are so small that most people wouldn’t even notice them. (paragraph 4)

Key.Rationale: The subtlety of elephants’ gestures is described in this sentence, but it is mentioned to describe an elephant’s body language, not how herds try to stay safe.

C.Choice: They think it may help the elephants focus all their attention on the sounds and smells around them. (paragraph 5)

Key.Rationale: When elephants perceive danger, sometimes the whole herd will freeze, which helps them “focus all their attention on the sounds and smells around them” to evaluate the situation in order to avoid danger.

D.Choice: If you ever wonder what an elephant is paying attention to, don’t watch its eyes. (paragraph 6)

Key.Rationale: The author includes this sentence to support the idea that elephants use their trunks, not their eyes, to pay attention to their surroundings, but it is not specified in this sentence that the elephant is paying attention to danger.

SubTopics: Make inferences and use evidence to support understanding.
Content: Based on information in paragraph 4, what can the reader infer about elephants?

F.Choice: An elephant’s ears help the elephant communicate.

Key.Rationale: The reader can infer from the idea that an “ear twitch may mean ‘I’m done here—let’s go’” that an elephant’s ears help the elephant communicate.

G.Choice: Elephants usually feel either happy or scared.

Key.Rationale: Elephants’ feelings of happiness and fear are mentioned in paragraph 5, not paragraph 4.

H.Choice: A large herd will rarely experience danger.

Key.Rationale: Danger and large elephant herds are not mentioned in paragraph 4.

J.Choice: Scientists are confused by an elephant’s body language.

Key.Rationale: The author explains the meaning of elephants’ body language in paragraph 4, so it is incorrect to infer that scientists are confused by an elephant’s body language.

SubTopics: Explain the author's purpose and message within a text.
Content: The author includes questions at the end of paragraph 6 most likely —

A.Choice: to show the details scientists want to learn about elephants

Key.Rationale: Scientists know that elephants use their trunk to smell and gather information. These are not questions about elephants that scientists are trying to answer through research.

B.Choice: to show that an elephant’s most important sense is the sense of smell

Key.Rationale: The author includes these questions to demonstrate an elephant’s sense of smell, not to rate it above other senses.

C.Choice: to show that elephants can identify members in their herd

Key.Rationale: These questions are used to suggest that elephants can do more than identify other elephants based on the way they smell.

D.Choice: to show that elephants gather information from different smells

Key.Rationale: By sniffing different smells with its trunk, the elephant can better understand its surroundings. The author includes questions to provide some examples of information elephants gather from smells, such as what food another elephant ate and what kind of animals are near.

SubTopics: Make inferences and use evidence to support understanding.
Content: How does Mom help Bella solve her problem?

F.Choice: She shows Bella different ways to improve as a speller.

Key.Rationale: Mom mentions she helped Bella study her spelling words in line 24 but does not show her “different ways to improve as a speller.”

G.Choice: She reminds Bella that she needs to play with her sister.

Key.Rationale: Mom explains that Samantha wants to rap like Bella (line 34) but does not say Bella should play with Samantha.

H.Choice: She convinces Bella that her rapping is a special talent.

Key.Rationale: After Mom explains that Samantha “thinks it’s cool” (line 34) when Bella rhymes and wants to create rhymes too, Bella realizes that putting together rhymes in her raps is a gift and not something to be embarrassed about (line 36).

J.Choice: She persuades Bella to forgive her classmate Amy.

Key.Rationale: Bella talks to Scott about Amy in lines 20 and 21, but Bella does not talk with Mom about Amy.

SubTopics: Use text evidence to support an appropriate response.
Content: Which line from the play suggests that Scott disagrees with Amy’s opinion of Bella?

A.Choice: SCOTT: Remember what I told you?

Key.Rationale: Scott’s response to Bella’s spelling problem is expressed in this line, not how Scott feels about Bella’s rapping or Amy’s opinion of it.

B.Choice: SCOTT: From what I can see, “shun” words aren’t easy for you.

Key.Rationale: Scott expresses an opinion about Bella’s spelling ability in this line, not what he thinks about Amy’s opinion of Bella’s rapping.

C.Choice: SCOTT: Besides, you’re really good at lots of other stuff.

Key.Rationale: Scott tries to make Bella feel better about not doing well on her spelling test in this line by assuring her that she is good at other things.

D.Choice: SCOTT: You should just keep on rapping.

Key.Rationale: Amy thinks Bella should stop rapping because it’s embarrassing when the kids laugh at her (lines 6-10). When Bella shares Amy’s opinion with Scott, he tells Bella to “just keep on rapping” because he believes her rhymes are funny and good, not embarrassing.

SubTopics: Use context within and beyond a sentence to determine the relevant meaning of unfamiliar words or multiple-meaning words.
Content: As it is used in line 28, the word e͟x͟c͟e͟l means to —

Key.Rationale: Bella and her mother are only discussing Bella’s concern with her spelling grade. Bella is not trying to do “many tasks at once” nor does her mother expect her to.

In line 27, Bella is concerned because she is “used to making good grades” but is not doing well in spelling. When Bella’s mother says “you can’t e͟x͟c͟e͟l at everything,” the reader can conclude from this context that Bella is better than others at certain things, such as rapping, but not spelling.
Bella realizes and admits that she has trouble with spelling; she is not pretending to know everything.

J.Choice: be afraid of trying new activities

Key.Rationale: Bella is not good at spelling. She is not afraid of trying different ways to improve her spelling.

SubTopics: Explain structure in drama such as character tags, acts, scenes, and stage directions.
Content: The reader can tell that “The Gift of Rhyme” is a play because it has a —

Key.Rationale: A well-known theme is something that is included in different types of literary genres, such as poems, stories, and plays, so a common theme is not a characteristic that is specific to a play.

The list of characters before scene 1 includes the characters’ names (BELLA, SCOTT, AMY, MOM, SAMANTHA) and information about who the characters are. The character list is included to help the reader identify this selection as a play.
Although Bella’s raps include rhyme, the other lines of the play are description and dialogue and do not have a rhyming pattern.
Many stories have a problem that is resolved, so it is not an element that is specific to the structure of a play.

SubTopics: Make inferences and use evidence to support understanding.
Content: Samantha’s rap in Scene 3 is important to the play because it helps Bella —

F.Choice: realize that her sister admires her raps

Key.Rationale: In scene 3, Samantha imitates Bella by creating a rap (line 30). Bella is surprised to hear Samantha rapping but realizes that Samantha raps because she admires Bella’s rapping.

G.Choice: discuss her concerns with her mother

Key.Rationale: Bella does discuss her concerns about spelling with her mother, but the beginning of that discussion is included in line 24 before Samantha’s rap in line 30.

H.Choice: understand why studying is so important

Key.Rationale: The amount of time Bella studied her spelling words is mentioned in line 24, but the idea of the importance of studying is not expressed in Samantha’s rap in line 30.

J.Choice: determine what has been wrong with her raps

Key.Rationale: Bella says she is “probably not ever going to be a renowned rapper” in line 33, but Samantha’s rap doesn’t help Bella determine problems with her raps.

SubTopics: Make inferences and use evidence to support understanding.
Content: Read this sentence from line 10.
:box:AMY: Look, if you had a piece of food stuck in your teeth, I would let you know.
This line is meant to show that Amy —

A.Choice: does not like to be told that she’s wrong

Key.Rationale: Amy is explaining why she is telling Bella her rapping is silly. Amy believes being truthful is being a good friend and is not concerned about what others think of her comments.

B.Choice: wishes that Bella wasn’t such a messy eater

Key.Rationale: Bella does not actually have food in her teeth, and Amy is not concerned about Bella being a messy eater.

C.Choice: thinks she’s being a good friend to Bella

Key.Rationale: Amy believes that telling Bella her rapping is silly is just as much of a favor as telling her if she had food in her teeth. Amy thinks she is helping Bella avoid any further embarrassment, which is what Amy believes good friends do for each other.

D.Choice: notices things that other people don’t see

Key.Rationale: Amy does not see food in Bella’s teeth. Amy just provides an example of why she is giving Bella advice.

SubTopics: Explain structure in drama such as character tags, acts, scenes, and stage directions.
Content: The playwright includes the stage directions at the beginning of each scene mainly to —

Key.Rationale: In line 1, the reader learns that events in scene 1 occur “in the school cafeteria” during lunch. In line 12, the reader learns that events in scene 2 occur in the “School hallway, one week later.” In line 23, the reader learns that events in scene 3 occur in the “Late afternoon, the same day” in Bella’s living room.

G.Choice: hint at how a problem will be solved

Key.Rationale: There is no mention of a problem or hints about how a problem will be solved in the stage directions at the beginning of each scene.
Bella begins to describe her problem with a spelling test in line 2. There is no mention of her problem in the stage directions at the beginning of each scene.

J.Choice: explain the characters’ feelings and actions

Key.Rationale: Although some characters’ actions are described in the stage directions, the characters’ feelings are not explained.

SubTopics: Make inferences and use evidence to support understanding.
Content: What can the reader tell about the article “The Broken-Crayon Solution” based on its title?

A.Choice: The article will most likely describe different ways to use crayons.

Key.Rationale: The reader does not get any hints that the article will be about different ways to use crayons from the words in the title, “The Broken-Crayon Solution.”

B.Choice: The article will most likely explain how crayons were invented.

Key.Rationale: The reader cannot infer that the article will be about how crayons were invented from the words in the title, “The Broken-Crayon Solution.”

C.Choice: The article will most likely explain an answer to a problem.

Key.Rationale: Based on the title “The Broken-Crayon Solution,” the reader can infer that the author will explain a problem with broken crayons and the solution to that problem in the article.

D.Choice: The article will most likely offer many uses for objects that are old.

Key.Rationale: Broken crayons are the only objects mentioned in the title.

SubTopics: Explain the author's purpose and message within a text.
Content: The most likely reason that the author provides the information in paragraph 1 of the article “The Broken-Crayon Solution” is —

F.Choice: to explain why Cassidy wanted to make her invention

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 1 of “The Broken-Crayon Solution,” the author describes that Cassidy realizes that her crayons were broken and difficult to use, which leads her to think of the invention.

G.Choice: to explain why Cassidy has so many crayons

Key.Rationale: The author does not imply in paragraph 1 that Cassidy has many crayons but does state that all of them were broken.

H.Choice: to explain who helped Cassidy to become an inventor

Key.Rationale: Cassidy is the only person the author mentions in paragraph 1.

J.Choice: to explain what color of crayon Cassidy likes best

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 1, the author does not mention specific colors but states that Cassidy “wanted to use every last stroke of color in each little crayon.”

SubTopics: Use text evidence to support an appropriate response.
Content: Which sentence from the article “The Broken-Crayon Solution” best supports the conclusion that Cassidy’s product was profitable?

A.Choice: She noticed that all of her crayons were broken. (paragraph 1)

Key.Rationale: There is no mention of Cassidy’s invention or its profits in this sentence.

B.Choice: Cassidy knew that her invention would make many young artists happy. (paragraph 3)

Key.Rationale: The effect of Cassidy’s invention on young artists is mentioned in this sentence, but not the profits Cassidy made from the invention.

C.Choice: Eventually so many crayon holders were sold that Cassidy was able to pay for most of her college education out of her earnings. (paragraph 3)

Key.Rationale: This sentence from “The Broken-Crayon Solution” can be used to support the conclusion that Cassidy made enough money (profit) from her invention “to pay for most of her college education.”

D.Choice: Cassidy’s invention encourages others to waste less. (paragraph 4)

Key.Rationale: The way that Cassidy’s invention affects others is mentioned in this sentence, but not the profits Cassidy made from the invention.

SubTopics: Use text evidence to support an appropriate response.
Content: Which sentence from the article “The Broken-Crayon Solution” supports the idea that the author likes Cassidy’s crayon holder?

Key.Rationale: In this sentence, the author states that Cassidy had an idea; the author does not state an opinion.

G.Choice: The ends of the tubes fit tightly around the crayons. (paragraph 2)

Key.Rationale: The author explains a fact about Cassidy’s invention but does not express an opinion in this sentence.

H.Choice: It could also hold a small broken one. (paragraph 2)

Key.Rationale: The author states a fact related to the usefulness of Cassidy’s invention but does not express an opinion in this sentence.

J.Choice: Cassidy’s invention is a brilliant idea. (paragraph 4)

Key.Rationale: In this sentence from “The Broken-Crayon Solution,” the author expresses the opinion that Cassidy’s idea for a crayon holder was brilliant.

SubTopics: Use context within and beyond a sentence to determine the relevant meaning of unfamiliar words or multiple-meaning words.
Content: In paragraph 3 of the selection “Bouncing Around,” what does the word refining mean?

Key.Rationale: In paragraphs 3 and 4 of “Bouncing Around,” the author describes changes Nissen made to improve his bouncer so that it could be springier when he jumped on it.
Nissen created and improved the bouncer in order to help develop his sports skills. It was when Nissen took the bouncer to a swim camp that he shared it with others.
Nissen took action to improve his bouncer; he was not just wishing for success.
Although Nissen continued refining the bouncer after he invented it, he was not trying to improve the bouncer as a way to plan for the future.

SubTopics: Analyze the author's use of print and graphic features to achieve specific purposes.
Content: What is the most likely reason the author included the photographs in the selection “Bouncing Around”?

F.Choice: To show that the trampoline was invented many years ago

Key.Rationale: It is mentioned in the caption of the first photograph that the photograph was taken in the year 2000, but that was not when the trampoline was invented.

G.Choice: To show that the trampoline can be used for different purposes

Key.Rationale: The photographs in “Bouncing Around” include an athlete on a trampoline while competing in the Olympics and a child “Having Fun on a Trampoline” in a backyard.

H.Choice: To show that people enjoy watching others use trampolines

Key.Rationale: There are other people watching the gymnast use the trampoline in the first photograph, but there is no one watching the girl in the second photograph.

J.Choice: To show that people can perform together on a trampoline

Key.Rationale: Both trampoline users are alone on the trampoline in each photograph.

SubTopics: Retell, paraphrase, or summarize texts in ways that maintain meaning and logical order.
Content: What is the best summary of the selection “Bouncing Around”?

A.Choice: The 2000 Olympic Games included a trampoline event for the first time. George Nissen, the inventor of the trampoline, always dreamed that his invention would one day be used in the Olympics.

Key.Rationale: There is too much emphasis on the Olympics in this summary. The purpose of the trampoline invention and its uses are missing from this summary, making it incomplete.

B.Choice: In high school George Nissen was a diver and gymnast. After watching a trapeze artist, he decided to make a bouncer in his garage. However, it did not work as he expected.

Key.Rationale: This summary is incomplete because there is no mention of Nissen’s success with the trampoline or its many uses.

C.Choice: The trampoline was invented by George Nissen, an athlete who wanted a new way to practice his skills. When Nissen began selling trampolines, many people bought them and used them for a variety of purposes.

Key.Rationale: The best summary of “Bouncing Around” is presented in these sentences. The main idea (how George Nissen invented the trampoline) and key details (the different ways trampolines can be used) are restated.

D.Choice: As a teenager George Nissen invented a bouncer he could use to jump on. He shared the bouncer with swimmers and divers at a swimming camp. They used the bouncer to practice flips and twists.

Key.Rationale: The author dedicates four paragraphs to describing why and how Nissen invented the trampoline, yet there is no mention of these important ideas in this summary.

SubTopics: Explain the author's purpose and message within a text.
Content: What is the most likely reason that the author includes the information in paragraph 8 of the selection “Bouncing Around”?

F.Choice: To compare how different types of athletes use Nissen’s invention

Key.Rationale: The Olympics are mentioned in paragraph 8, but the ways different types of athletes use trampolines are not mentioned.

G.Choice: To show that Nissen’s invention is still enjoyable and useful for many people

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 8 of “Bouncing Around,” the reader can infer from the author’s description “Today kids and adults jump on trampolines in gyms and backyards to stay active and healthy” that many people still use and appreciate Nissen’s trampoline.

H.Choice: To describe how Nissen feels about his invention years after he made it

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 8, the author does not include Nissen’s opinion of the trampoline.

J.Choice: To explain when Nissen’s invention was first used in the Olympics

Key.Rationale: The Olympics are mentioned in paragraph 8, but no date is given.

SubTopics: Make connections to personal experiences, ideas in other texts, and society.
Content: What is a way that Cassidy’s crayon holders in the article “The Broken-Crayon Solution” differ from Nissen’s trampoline in the selection “Bouncing Around”?

A.Choice: Only the crayon holders were made while the inventor was in college.

Key.Rationale: Cassidy in “The Broken-Crayon Solution” earned enough money for college (paragraph 3) by inventing the crayon holder when she was 11 (paragraph 1).

B.Choice: Only the crayon holders help make a common object easier to use.

Key.Rationale: Cassidy’s crayon holders described in “The Broken-Crayon Solution” make crayons (a common object) easier to use. The trampoline in “Bouncing Around” is an invention that people use for a variety of purposes (exercise, fun, and Olympic sports, for example), not something that makes a common object easier to use.

C.Choice: Only the crayon holders can be used to help improve a skill.

Key.Rationale: Nissen created the trampoline with the goal of using it to “improve his tumbling and diving” (paragraph 3 of “Bouncing Around”).

D.Choice: Only the crayon holders can be used by children.

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 8 of “Bouncing Around,” the author includes the statement “kids and adults jump on trampolines,” so children can also use trampolines.

SubTopics: Make connections to personal experiences, ideas in other texts, and society.
Content: Which statement best describes a difference between Cassidy in the article “The Broken-Crayon Solution” and Nissen in the selection “Bouncing Around”?

F.Choice: Cassidy found it easy to sell her product, but Nissen found it difficult.

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 7 of “Bouncing Around,” the author explains that “Nissen opened a store and sold trampolines,” but there is no mention that they were difficult to sell.

G.Choice: Cassidy was not happy with her invention at first, but Nissen was pleased with his at first.

Key.Rationale: Cassidy was happy with her invention right away (paragraph 2 of “The Broken-Crayon Solution”), whereas Nissen spent time improving his inventions (paragraphs 3 and 4 of “Bouncing Around”).

H.Choice: Cassidy got the idea for her invention at a public event, but Nissen thought of his idea at home.

Key.Rationale: In “The Broken-Crayon Solution,” it is not specified where Cassidy was when she got the idea for her invention, whereas Nissen thought of his idea at a public event, the circus (paragraph 2 of “Bouncing Around”).

J.Choice: Cassidy made her product to avoid waste, but Nissen made his for exercise.

Key.Rationale: Cassidy made her crayon holders to avoid wasting crayons that were broken and difficult to use (paragraph 1 of “The Broken-Crayon Solution”). Nissen made his trampoline for exercise because he wanted to “improve his tumbling and diving” (paragraph 3 of “Bouncing Around”).

SubTopics: Make connections to personal experiences, ideas in other texts, and society.
Content: What is one way the article “The Broken-Crayon Solution” and the selection “Bouncing Around” are different?

A.Choice: “The Broken-Crayon Solution” tells about a short period in Cassidy’s life. “Bouncing Around” describes several years of Nissen’s life.

Key.Rationale: In “The Broken-Crayon Solution,” the author tells about a short period in Cassidy’s life, from when she was 11 years old until she was in college. In “Bouncing Around,” the author describes several years of Nissen’s life, from before 1934 all the way up until the year 2000.

B.Choice: “The Broken-Crayon Solution” explains many benefits of Cassidy’s product. “Bouncing Around” suggests that there is only one benefit from using Nissen’s product.

Key.Rationale: This is a similarity instead of a difference because there are multiple benefits for each product.

C.Choice: “The Broken-Crayon Solution” describes the steps Cassidy used to make her invention. “Bouncing Around” does not tell how Nissen made his invention.

Key.Rationale: In paragraphs 2 and 3 of “Bouncing Around,” the author tells how Nissen made the trampoline.

D.Choice: “The Broken-Crayon Solution” shows that Cassidy had many interests as a child. “Bouncing Around” shows Nissen had only one interest.

Key.Rationale: Only one of Cassidy’s interests (drawing) is discussed in “The Broken-Crayon Solution,” whereas Nissen enjoyed “tumbling and diving” in “Bouncing Around” (paragraph 3).

SubTopics: Make connections to personal experiences, ideas in other texts, and society.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 3 of the selection “Bouncing Around.”
:box:So, in his garage, Nissen tied heavy canvas to a steel frame.
Which sentence from paragraph 1 of the article “The Broken-Crayon Solution” describes in a similar way what led to building an invention?

F.Choice: One day 11-year-old Cassidy Goldstein was trying to work on an art project.

Key.Rationale: Nissen was not working on a project when he thought of his invention; he was at a circus, so Cassidy “trying to work on an art project” is not similar to the idea expressed in the sentence from “Bouncing Around.”

G.Choice: She noticed that all of her crayons were broken.

Key.Rationale: Cassidy noticing broken crayons is not similar to Nissen building a trampoline, as described in the sentence from “Bouncing Around.”

H.Choice: Then Cassidy found some plastic tubes used to hold single-cut flowers.

Key.Rationale: In this sentence from “The Broken-Crayon Solution,” the author describes the plastic tubes Cassidy used in her invention. Similarly, the author of “Bouncing Around” describes the canvas and steel frame Nissen used to create the trampoline in his garage. In each sentence, the author describes materials the person used to accomplish a goal or solve a problem.

J.Choice: She would make her own crayon holders.

Key.Rationale: Specific materials that Cassidy used to make her crayon holders are not mentioned in this sentence, so this is not similar to the idea expressed in the sentence from “Bouncing Around.”

SubTopics: Use print or digital resources to determine meaning, syllabication, and pronunciation.
Content: Read this dictionary entry.

:box:scale \'skāl\ noun
1. one of the small, hard parts that covers a fish
2. a tool for measuring heaviness
3. a series of musical notes
4. a set of marks in a row used to measure distance
Which definition most closely fits the way the word s͟c͟a͟l͟e is used in line 20?

Key.Rationale: A fish is mentioned in the poem, but the s͟c͟a͟l͟e is not part of the fish. It is an object the speaker ran to get and used to weigh the fish.
The speaker mentions the size of the fish in line 19, and then she and her brother use a s͟c͟a͟l͟e to weigh the fish.
There is no mention of sounds or music in relation to the fish the speaker describes.
The speaker and her brother are measuring the fish’s weight, not a distance.

SubTopics: Make inferences and use evidence to support understanding.
Content: Based on details in the poem, which statement best describes how the speaker most likely feels about Max?

F.Choice: She wishes he would listen to her.

Key.Rationale: There is no context to support the idea that the speaker wishes Max would listen to her.
The speaker describes Max in a positive way, so there is no context to support the idea that she is jealous of him.

In line 16, the speaker says “Sometimes he let me carry his fishing pole,” which suggests that the speaker feels it was an honor or privilege to do so. The speaker also sat next to Max while fishing and is impressed by Max in line 19, saying “Max caught the biggest fish any of us ever saw.”
Max is never in any danger, so there is no context to support the idea that the speaker wishes to protect him.

SubTopics: Make inferences and use evidence to support understanding.
Content: What is the most likely reason the poet includes the seasons in the poem?

A.Choice: To explain the safest time of year to travel by boat on the river

Key.Rationale: Neither safety nor danger is ever mentioned in the poem, so there is no context to support this reason.

B.Choice: To suggest when the speaker likes to fish in the river

Key.Rationale: In line 18, the speaker references the “smell of the summer river”; however, there is no context to support the idea that summer is the speaker’s favorite season for fishing in the river.

C.Choice: To identify the best time of year to make friends at the river

Key.Rationale: The speaker mentions going to the river with her friend Sarah (line 5) but does not say that she became friends with Sarah at the river.

D.Choice: To highlight when the speaker observes changes in the river

Key.Rationale: The reader can conclude that the poet highlights when the speaker observes changes in the river by including the seasons. During the winter, Sarah and the speaker “walked across the river” (line 7) because it was frozen. The river was full during the spring (line 11) and was muddy when they fished in the summer (line 18).

SubTopics: Describe how the author's use of imagery, literal and figurative language such as simile and metaphor, and sound devices such as alliteration and assonance achieves specific purposes.
Content: In line 2, “like a fat brown thread” suggests that the river —

F.Choice: is full of many kinds of fish

Key.Rationale: The poet includes “like a fat brown thread” to describe the river, not different kinds of fish in the river.

G.Choice: makes a wide path through the land

Key.Rationale: The poet describes the river wiggling through the land (line 1) and specifies that the river is wide (fat) in line 2, looking “like a fat brown thread” to the speaker.
The poet is describing how the river looks as it moves through the land, not what it is filled with.
The passing of time is not mentioned in line 2, and there is no context to support the idea that the river gets a darker shade of brown.

SubTopics: Make inferences and use evidence to support understanding.
Content: Read lines 13 and 14 from the poem.

:box:leaving chunks of trees
that we made into pirate ships.
What do these lines suggest about the speaker’s experience at the river?

A.Choice: The river creates problems that the speaker wants to avoid.

Key.Rationale: The poet does not use negative language regarding the “chunks of trees,” so there is no context to support the idea that the river creates a problem for the speaker.

B.Choice: The river gives the speaker a chance to travel to new places.

Key.Rationale: The speaker does not say she rides on the “pirate ships,” just that she makes them from tree chunks.

C.Choice: The river provides a way for the speaker to be creative.

Key.Rationale: When the river floods, it brings parts of trees, perhaps branches and trunks, that the speaker and Sarah use to create “pirate ships.”

D.Choice: The river can be a confusing place for the speaker.

Key.Rationale: The speaker does not express any confusion in these lines. She describes exactly what she does with the pieces of trees.

SubTopics: Make inferences and use evidence to support understanding.
Content: Based on details in the story, what can the reader infer about Phineas?

F.Choice: He is excited about making the meal for his family.

Key.Rationale: At the beginning of the story, Phineas excitedly gathers supplies, runs up the stairs to get a shirt to wear as a lab coat, and makes a plan for the dinner.

G.Choice: He likes cooking more than he likes science.

Key.Rationale: Phineas models his cooking experiment after a science experiment because he considers himself a scientist, but there is no text evidence to support that he likes cooking more than he likes science.

H.Choice: He feels confused by the unusual items in the kitchen.

Key.Rationale: Phineas does not know how to use the stove or how to open the sauce, but he does not think these are unusual kitchen items.

J.Choice: He has cooked meals for his family before.

Key.Rationale: Phineas makes a plan for dinner in paragraph 2, but there is no text evidence to support the idea that he has cooked before, especially since he does not know how to use the stove.

SubTopics: Make inferences and use evidence to support understanding.
Content: Which conclusion about Phineas is best supported by the list at the end of the story?

A.Choice: He hopes he never has to cook again.

Key.Rationale: Phineas is suggesting that he has learned some things about cooking, but there is no context to support the idea that he never wants to cook again.

B.Choice: He discovers that cooking is easier than he thought.

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 3, Phineas says that his plan for cooking dinner is “Easy peasy.” However, Phineas makes a lot of mistakes that ruin the dinner, so the reader can conclude that Phineas thinks cooking is more difficult than he thought.

C.Choice: He realizes he made some mistakes while cooking.

Key.Rationale: In the list at the end of the story, Phineas writes everything he learned from his experiment, which is the result of the mistakes he made: the spaghetti clumps, the sauce burns and sticks to the bottom of the pot, there is too much pasta, and the pasta disintegrates from cooking too long.

D.Choice: He decides that pasta is his favorite meal to cook.

Key.Rationale: Phineas’ pasta is not something the family could eat for dinner. Although Phineas learned some valuable lessons, there’s no text evidence to suggest pasta is his favorite meal to cook.

SubTopics: Use text evidence to support an appropriate response.
Content: Which sentence from the story suggests that Phineas is embarrassed to ask for help?

Key.Rationale: Phineas is not showing or expressing any emotion in this sentence.

G.Choice: I’m not allowed to use the stove. (paragraph 5)

Key.Rationale: Phineas is recognizing a problem, but he is not showing that he is embarrassed.

H.Choice: I felt my face turn red. (paragraph 8)

Key.Rationale: In this sentence, the author suggests that Phineas is embarrassed to ask for help. When someone’s face turns red, it is often a result of being embarrassed.

J.Choice: I couldn’t get the lid off the jar. (paragraph 12)

Key.Rationale: Phineas is identifying a problem he encounters while trying to cook the dinner. He has not yet asked for help with opening the jar, so he is not embarrassed.

SubTopics: Explain the interactions of the characters and the changes they undergo.
Content: Sarah’s conversations with Phineas show that Sarah —

A.Choice: does not think Phineas is old enough to cook

Key.Rationale: Sarah does not express any thoughts about Phineas’ age and does not criticize him when he tries to cook.

B.Choice: does not mind helping Phineas in the kitchen

Key.Rationale: Sarah does not seem to mind showing Phineas how to turn the stove on or open the sauce. She just says “‘There’s a first time for everything’” (paragraphs 9 and 13) and helps him.

C.Choice: is surprised at how much Phineas wants to cook

Key.Rationale: Sarah shows no signs of surprise when she sees Phineas trying to cook a dinner.

D.Choice: wishes Phineas was better at following directions

Key.Rationale: Sarah helps Phineas do things that do not have directions. Her opinions about the pasta, which comes with directions, are not given.

SubTopics: Identify and understand the use of literary devices, including first- or third-person point of view.
Content: Which sentence best helps the reader understand that the story is told from the first-person point of view?

F.Choice: The stove was a giant Bunsen burner, and the pots and pans were beakers and flasks. (paragraph 1)

Key.Rationale: There are no pronouns in this sentence to help the reader understand that the author used a first-person point of view in the story.

G.Choice: Sarah came in from the living room. (paragraph 7)

Key.Rationale: In this sentence, the narrator is describing what Sarah is doing. There are no pronouns to help the reader determine that first-person point of view is used in the story.

H.Choice: Then she showed me what I needed to do. (paragraph 10)

Key.Rationale: Point of view is the perspective from which the events in the story are told. In the first-person point of view, the narrator tells the story from the narrator’s perspective and uses the word “I.”

J.Choice: Sarah wrapped the lid with one of the yellow rubber gloves by the sink, took a deep breath, and twisted. (paragraph 14)

Key.Rationale: Details about Sarah’s actions are described in this sentence. This description does not include pronouns that would help the reader understand that the story is told from the first-person point of view.
